The '''Rivian R1S''' is an [[Electric vehicle|all-electric]], full-size [[Off-road vehicle|off-road]] [[SUV]] manufactured by [[Rivian Automotive]]. Customer deliveries started in 2022.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.teslarati.com/rivian-r1s-customer-deliveries/ | title=Rivian starts R1S customer deliveries | date=29 August 2022 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=2022 Rivian R1S SUV: Review, Trims, Specs, Price, New Interior Features, Exterior Design, and Specifications |url=https://carbuzz.com/cars/rivian/r1s |access-date=2022-06-12 |website=CarBuzz |language=en-us}}<!-- CarBuzz is another poor source, recycling as "2022" old prose written more than a year ago.  The CarBuzz article says this: "The R1S is expected to go on sale in early 2021." --></ref> The car took nearly 10 years to develop.<ref name=carsdotcomDateUnknown/> Depending on the configuration, it has either two or four electric [[motor]]s.<ref name=carsdotcomDateUnknown>{{Cite web |title=2022 Rivian R1S Overview - An expert's take |first = Joe | last = Wiesenfelder | url=https://www.cars.com/research/rivian-r1s-2022/ |date=<!-- date of article is missing; title implies 2022, yet text in the article indicates the text is older than 2022 by several years, including this statement: "The Plymouth, Mich.-based company says the real products will arrive in late 2020." --> |website=cars.com |access-date=12 June 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=R1S - Rivian |url=https://rivian.com/r1s |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221030232745/https://rivian.com/r1s |archive-date=31 October 2022 |access-date=31 October 2022 |website=Rivian}}</ref>{{better source|date=June 2022}}

==Design==
[[File:Rivian R1S, Howard Ave, Burlingame 2.jpg|thumb|left|Rear view, Launch Edition (Oct 2022)]] It is designed to hold seven passengers and accelerate from [[0 to 60 mph]] (0 to 97 km/h) in 3 seconds, due to its {{Convert|835|Hp|kW PS|abbr=on}} combined output power.<ref name=car&d20220303>{{Cite web |date=2022-03-03 |title=2022 Rivian R1S: What We Know So Far |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/rivian/r1s |access-date=2022-06-12 |website=Car and Driver |language=en-us}}</ref> It shares 91% of its components with the [[Rivian R1T]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=Inside the automotive startup taking EVs off-road |url=https://www.engadget.com/2018-05-21-rivian-ev-truck-suv-detroit.html |access-date=2022-06-27 |website=Engadget |language=en-US}}</ref> Rivian's flat, low [[center of gravity]] chassis makes it an "electric vehicle [[skateboard]]".<ref>{{Cite web |title=Rivian Reveals 'Skateboard' Chassis At Michigan Conference |url=https://www.wglt.org/show/wglts-sound-ideas/2018-06-19/rivian-reveals-skateboard-chassis-at-michigan-conference |access-date=2022-06-27 |website=WGLT |language=en}}</ref> The vehicle is equipped for semi-autonomous driving according to level 3 and designed for road traffic and off-road driving.

===Powertrain===
As announced in 2018, the R1S was planned to be offered with three different traction battery capacities and power outputs; all planned versions included four traction motors.<ref name=CD-2018>{{cite news |url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a25323098/2022-rivian-r1s-electric-suv-photos-info/ |title=The 2021 Rivian R1S Is an Electric Seven-Passenger SUV Claiming Supercar Acceleration |author=Golson, Daniel |date=November 27, 2018 |work=Car and Driver |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> Each wheel is driven by an independent traction motor, allowing full-time [[all-wheel drive]] with [[torque vectoring]].<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/> The quad-motor version uses electric traction motors developed by [[Robert Bosch GmbH]], but these are carried on the vehicle's frame; the R1S does not use [[wheel hub motor]]s like the [[Lordstown Endurance]].<ref name=iEVs-Kane2203/> As delivered in 2022, the quad-motor R1S has a combined output of {{cvt|835|hp}} and {{cvt|908|lbft}}, split {{cvt|415|/|420|hp}} and {{cvt|413|/|495|lbft}} front/rear.<ref name=MT-1st/>

Rivian has announced plans to reduce prices by offering dual-motor versions starting in 2024, with independent traction motors for the front and rear axles,<ref name=IEVs-2022-03>{{cite news |url=https://insideevs.com/news/570503/rivian-dual-motor-price-increase/ |title=Rivian Announces Dual Motor And Smaller Battery Options; Hefty Price Increases |author=Moloughney, Tom |date=March 1, 2022 |work=Inside EVs |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> using motors developed by Rivian.<ref name=iEVs-Kane2203>{{cite news |url=https://insideevs.com/news/572896/rivian-new-tech-under-development/ |title=Rivian Announces New Tech Under Development |author=Kane, Mark |date=March 12, 2022 |work=Inside EVs |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> Dual-motor versions are expected to offer the same choice of three different battery capacities, with slightly greater corresponding range as the weight and efficiency should improve with two motors.<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/> Maximum output of the dual-motor version is expected to be >{{cvt|600|hp}} and >{{cvt|600|lbft}}, which is a decrease from the quad-motor version.<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/>

The extended range ("Max Pack") battery has been delayed until 2023.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thedrive.com/tech/43691/rivian-delays-400-mile-max-battery-and-base-model-r1t-r1s-until-2023 |title=Rivian Delays 400+ Mile Max Battery and Base Model R1T, R1S Until 2023 |author=Stumpf, Rob |date=January 3, 2022 |work=The Drive |access-date=1 November 2022}}</ref> In addition, the smaller ("Standard") battery is not scheduled to be delivered until 2024; the Standard battery will use [[lithium iron phosphate]] (LFP) chemistry to reduce costs by eliminating nickel and cobalt.<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/10/rivian-changing-battery-cells-to-lfp-following-tesla-and-high-nickel.html |title=Rivian will follow Tesla and change the type of battery cells it uses in standard packs |author=Kolodny, Lara |date=March 10, 2022 |work=CNBC |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

===Consumption and performance===
The 2022 Rivian R1S was rated by the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] with a consumption of {{cvt|69|mpge}} for the combined city+highway driving cycle and a total range of {{cvt|316|mi}} when equipped with the "Large" 135 kW-hr battery and quad-motor drivetrain.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fueleconomy.gov/feg/Find.do?action=sbs&id=44461 |title=2022 Rivian R1S |website=fueleconomy.gov |publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

Acceleration from 0 to {{cvt|60|mph}} was tested by ''[[Motor Trend]]'' in August 2022 at 3.1 seconds on all-season tires and 3.2 seconds on all-terrain tires. Corresponding {{cvt|1/4|mi}} elapsed times and trap speeds were 11.6 sec at {{cvt|111.2|mph}} on all-season tires, slowing to 11.8 sec at {{cvt|111.6|mph}} with all-terrain tires.<ref name=MT-1st/>

===Storage and towing===
[[File:Rivian_SUV_frunk.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.2|The frunk of a Rivian R1S]]
Total enclosed cargo volume is {{cvt|104.7|cuft}} when the second and third rows are folded down. There is a front trunk (aka "frunk") is under the [[Hood (car)|hood]], where the engine is in most conventional internal combustion engine vehicles, which adds {{cvt|11.1|cuft}} of lockable storage.<ref name=gearpatrol.com>{{cite news |url=https://www.gearpatrol.com/cars/g40466277/2022-rivian-r1s-review/ |title=2022 Rivian R1S Review: Somehow, More Game-Changing Than Its Truck Brother |last=Mazzucchi |first=Steve |date=6 July 2022 |work=Gear Patrol |access-date=22 July 2022}}</ref> In addition, there is a small compartment underneath the cargo floor.<ref name=MT-1st/>

Towing capacity is {{cvt|7700|lb}}.<ref name=rivian.com/r1s>{{cite news |url=https://rivian.com/r1s |title=R1S - Rivian}}</ref><ref name=Wired-2022-08>{{cite news |url=https://www.wired.com/review/rivian-r1t-and-r1s/ |title=Review: Rivian R1T and R1S |author=Jancer, Matt |date=August 30, 2022 |work=Wired |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

===Interior===
Pet comfort mode maintains a user-selected temperature inside the car when the driver is away from the vehicle.<ref name="gearpatrol.com" /> A five-passenger option deleting the third row was discontinued in March 2022 before production vehicles began to be delivered; all R1Ss are seven-passenger, three-row vehicles.<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/> Third-row seating was reported to be "a little tight for adults", with low cushion height resulting in most people adopting a posture with knees higher than their hips.<ref name=MT-1st/>

The glass roof is not equipped with a sunshade and the resulting insolation made ''Motor Trend'' reviewers uncomfortable during comparison testing in the desert at temperatures exceeding {{cvt|100|F}}. The same reviewers criticized the infotainment system, which is not equipped with [[Apple CarPlay]] or [[Android Auto]].<ref name=MT-SUVOTY>{{cite news |url=https://www.motortrend.com/news/2022-rivian-r1s-electric-suv-pros-cons-review/ |title=2022 Rivian R1S SUVOTY Review: You'll Be Floored When You're not Roasting |author=Loh, Edward |date=October 19, 2022 |work=Motor Trend |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

===Chassis===
The vehicle has an air suspension which allows for a maximum ground clearance of {{cvt|14.9|in}}, with individual wheels cross-linked to reduce body lean during cornering. In addition, there is a "Camp Mode" that allows the vehicle to level itself when parked on irregular terrain.<ref name=MT-SUVOTY/> Maximum wading depth in water is {{cvt|43.1|in|m}}.<ref name=motortrend.com>{{cite news |url=https://www.motortrend.com/reviews/2022-rivian-r1s-first-drive-review/ |title=2022 Rivian R1S Electric SUV First Drive: Is Shorter Sweeter? |last=Markus |first=Frank |date=6 July 2022 |work=Motor Trend |access-date=22 July 2022}}</ref>

Compared to the R1T, which has a {{cvt|135.8|in}} wheelbase, the R1S rides on a shorter {{cvt|121.1|in}} wheelbase and has a shorter rear overhang, improving [[Approach and departure angles|departure]] and [[breakover angle]]s.<ref name=Wired-2022-08/> This also results in a [[turning circle]] that is nearly {{cvt|4|ft}} smaller for the R1S.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.motortrend.com/reviews/2022-rivian-r1t-yearlong-review-update-3-versus-r1s/ |title=What's the Difference Between a Rivian R1S and a Rivian R1T? |author1=Evans, Scott |author2=Walker, William |date=October 11, 2022 |work=Motor Trend |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

===Trim levels===
The entry-level trim was called the Explore package, which included matte-black interior finishes and heated vegan leather seats.<ref name=Cars-Explore>{{cite news |url=https://www.cars.com/articles/rivian-drops-most-affordable-explore-package-for-r1t-r1s-455841/ |title=Rivian Drops Most Affordable Explore Package for R1T, R1S |author=Ulitskaya, Jane |date=August 22, 2022 |website=cars.com |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> In August 2022, Rivian announced it had discontinued the Explore package<ref name=Verge22/> citing low demand, simplified assembly and supply chain constraints that would be alleviated with a single option. By eliminating the base trim, Rivian effectively increased prices.<ref name=Cars-Explore/>

The Adventure package upgrades the interior with heated and cooled perforated vegan leather seats, Chilewich woven floor mats, wood or vegan leather accents, and a premium Rivian Elevation sound system designed by [[Meridian Audio]] which includes a removable [[Bluetooth]] speaker.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web |url=https://rivian.com/support/article/whats-included-in-the-adventure-package |title=What's included in the Adventure Package |publisher=Rivian |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

The limited-availability Launch edition included the Adventure package, the large battery, an exclusive Launch green color, and an option to upgrade wheels and tires at no additional cost.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |title=Compare Rivian R1S SUV Adventure vs Explore vs Launch Edition |url=https://carbuzz.com/compare/rivian-r1s-suv-adventure-vs-explore-vs-launch-edition |access-date=2022-07-21 |website=CarBuzz |language=en-us}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://rivian.com/support/article/what-is-launch-edition |title=What is Launch Edition |publisher=Rivian |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>

==History==
[[File:Debut of the Rivian R1S SUV at the 2018 Los Angeles Auto Show, November 27, 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Concept Rivian R1S at the Nov 2018 [[Los Angeles Auto Show|LA Auto Show]]]]
The Rivian R1S debuted as a [[concept car|prototype model]] first shown at the [[Los Angeles Auto Show]] in November 2018.<ref name=carsdotcomDateUnknown/> The prototype shown in LA was said to be in "production form".<ref name=CD-2018/> By December 2019, Rivian had raised $1.3 billion in new funding for this and the [[Rivian R1T|R1T Truck]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=2019-12-23 |title=Electric-Truck Maker Rivian Raises $1.3 Billion in New Funding |language=en |work=Bloomberg.com |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2019-12-23/electric-truck-maker-rivian-raises-1-3-billion-led-by-t-rowe |access-date=2022-06-27}}</ref>

===Delivery delays===
The first two R1S vehicles were delivered to the CEO, R.J. Scaringe, and the SFO, Claire McDonough, in December 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/rivian-r1s-suv-delivery-production/ |title=Rivian delivers first R1S electric SUVs |author=Golson, Daniel |date=December 20, 2021 |work=Road/Show |publisher=CNet |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> Rivian announced in mid-June 2022 that there would be a delay for some deliveries of its R1S electric SUV. The company cites the delay is due to supply chain issues and limited service infrastructure.<ref name="reviewgeek.com">{{cite news |last=Gunther |first=Cory |date=15 June 2022 |title=Rivian Delays Delivery of Its R1S Electric SUV, Again |work=Review Geek |url=https://www.reviewgeek.com/120950/rivian-delays-delivery-of-its-r1s-electric-suv-again/ |access-date=18 June 2022}}</ref> Deliveries to customers began in late August 2022.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://electrek.co/2022/08/27/rivian-delivering-r1s/ |title=Rivian begins delivering its R1S electric SUV to customers |author=Dow, Jameson |date=August 27, 2022 |work=Electrek |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> The first vehicles to be released were equipped with the large (135 kW/hr) battery and quad-motor drivetrain.<ref name=MT-SUVOTY/>

=== Price changes ===
In March 2022, Rivian announced the price of the R1S would increase by 20%, jumping to $84,500 from $70,000 for the base model.<ref name=IEVs-2022-03/><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/rivian-hikes-vehicle-prices-by-20-citing-inflationary-pressure-2022-03-02/ |title=Rivian raises EV prices by 20%, inviting customer ire, taunt from Musk |author=Jin, Hyunjoo |date=March 1, 2022 |work=Reuters |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> After receiving negative feedback, Rivian honored the original prices for pre-orders made before the price increase.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2022/03/03/rivian-rolls-back-big-price-increases-on-pre-orders-after-customer-backlash.html |title=Rivian rolls back big price increases on preorders after customer backlash |author=Rosevear, John |date=March 3, 2022 |work=CNBC |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref><ref name=GQ-2022>{{cite news |url=https://www.gq.com/story/rivian-r1s-worlds-most-hyped-electric-suv |title=Behind the Wheel of the Rivian R1S, the World's Most Hyped Electric SUV |author=Baldwin, Rosecrans |date=August 16, 2022 |work=Gentleman's Quarterly |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref> In August 2022, Rivian cancelled the base Explore trim level, forcing people who pre-ordered the Explore to either cancel or upgrade to the more expensive Adventure trim.<ref name=Verge22>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/8/18/23312081/rivian-r1t-r1s-price-increase-explore-package-discontinued |title=Some Rivian customers aren't happy the company canceled its most affordable electric truck |author=Clark, Mitchell |date=August 18, 2022 |work=The Verge |access-date=26 October 2022}}</ref>
